pageSummary: Walking, running or cycling 877.8km in 4 weeks because 165,000 people die from cancer each year
pageSummaryWhat: Walking, running or cycling 877.8km in 4 weeks
pageSummaryWhy: 165,000 people die from cancer each year
story:
There are 165,000 deaths from cancer each year, 38% of these are
classed as preventable (ref from cancer research statistics page).

That means there are (roughly) 62,700 preventable deaths
from cancer every year! This is such a drastic and tragic occurrence in today’s day and age.

To raise money and awareness of this, every member of the
London team will run/walk/cycle 62,700 metres over the next 4 weeks. 

Thanks for supporting our fundraising. Macmillan Cancer Support is here to help everyone with cancer live life as fully as they can, providing physical, financial and emotional support. So whatever cancer throws your way, they're right there with you.

story:
Some of you may / may not know that in July, John's mum Ann passed away and in September I was diagnosed with breast cancer. So it's been a bit of a year. 

But along the way we have met doctors, nurses and volunteers who have not only been ridiculously kind but frighteningly competent and, quite frankly extraordinary. 

So instead of Xmas presents this year, we would like to raise some money for them. We realise the year's been tough for everyone but if you can spare a tenner or so - it would really be appreciated.

And thank you from the bottom of our hearts.

Jackie & John x

story:
We're collecting vital funds for the British Heart Foundation, to power pioneering research into heart and cardiovascular diseases. The money we raise will help beat heartbreak forever.

The British Heart Foundation tend to have a reputation as an old persons charity, but over 4,000 babies are diagnosed with a heart condition in the UK every year. 

Prior to the establishment of the foundation, 4 in 5 babies born with a heart condition would not make it to their first birthday. Nowadays, those 4 in 5 will become adults, thanks to the work of the British Heart Foundation.

Dad battled for almost 20 years with his heart, the NHS were amazing in their care, he had heart surgery, a number of stent procedures and all the drugs in between to keep him going.

As a result he was able to see his existing and new grandchildren grow, learn a new skill playing guitar, which he’d always thought he was too old to do amongst realising many other aspects of life he would not have realised with the extension of life changing drugs

Sadly dad lost his battle with heart disease this month and it has ironically broken many hearts as a result, as he was loved by many and held in our hearts always

story:
I lost both of my grandparents on 5th March 2020 due to dementia and cancer. This has been a dreadful year for so many people worldwide, but after thinking about it for a while, I would like to do something positive in their memory before the end of the year.

Due to so many restrictions in society at the moment, I thought about what I could do to raise money and decided that something which could be done remotely might be the way forward. Therefore, using the treadmill in my garage, I am planning to run 150km between 25th November and 24th December. I will give daily updates on Facebook with screenshots and total distance run.

The two charities I am raising money for are Alzheimer Scotland and Cancer Research UK.

Unfortunately, I had to create two separate pages for both charities and then made a team page, which does make it a bit more awkward. Ideally, I would like to keep funds as equal as possible, but understand that might not happen.

Thank you for taking the time to read this. Hopefully the targets for both charities can be reached and thanks in advance for any donations you give.

story:
George Edward Smith - 7/12/35-17/11/20

George requested no flowers at his funeral. 

We know that he was a supporter of RNLI. Dad was born and brought up in Buckie, Scotland and had many sea faring friends and family. He admired the vital life saving work the RLNI do every day. 

Aileen, Carol and Graham would like to send our thanks and gratitude to all of the Medical, Nursing and Careline staff who helped to care for our lovely Dad over the past months.

You gave us precious time together.

We would also like to thank Dad's neighbours for being good friends and for all the messages of condolence from family and friends around the world.

Here is one of the poems we will read at Dad's funeral, George loved poetry and Robert Burns in particular, this poem exemplifies many of George's best qualities.

An Epitaph to a Friend - Robert Burns

An honest man here lies at rest,

The friend of man, the friend of truth,

The friend of age, and guide of youth:

Few hearts like his, with virtue warm'd,

Few heads with knowledge so inform'd;

If there's another world, he lives in bliss;

If there is none, he made the best of this.


The photo here is of Dad on his 84th birthday, he missed his 85th by  less than 3 weeks. Raise a glass for George.


George's funeral will be at Darlington Crematorium, 1:15pm on Monday 30th November 2020. Due to Covid Restrictions it will be a small gathering of immediate family and close friends, we are sorry we are unable to extend an invitation to all.

pageSummary: In memory of Ross L Armstrong because every father, husband, son knows their value.
pageSummaryWhat: In memory of Ross L Armstrong
pageSummaryWhy: every father, husband, son knows their value.
story:
A son to Murdo and Aileen, a brother to Murray - Ross always spoke fondly of his experiences growing up in the north of Scotland, which gave him a life-long love for the Highlands as a place he loved to be.

A loving husband to Lucy - you made him a very happy man.  Ross always felt he was the luckiest man to have met you.

A very proud Father to his long-awaited daughter Yula:  You made his achievements worthwhile and he remained supportive of everything  you chose to do and the path you wish to follow.

Ross graduated in engineering and started work at Motorola in East Kilbride.  From there he moved to the village of Ochiltree in Ayrshire, where in true Ross form, he took on the locals as friends.  There are so many great and comic stories of his exploits renovating the house, canoeing adventures in the local rivers, walking in the hills and of course the local pub – each and every one a legend.

At Digital, Ross easily progressed from engineering to managing the design business and worked in locations all over the world from Ayr, Irvine, Loughborough, Munich and Phoenix. Ross shone as a leader, and his promotion to Director of the Design Team in Irvine was the obvious choice.  Following a brief spell in Loughborough, Ross then moved to Germany for a couple of years, where he actually purchased some lederhosen – a sight which made the German team love him – how could they not?  His final career move was to Phoenix, Arizona where in true Ross style he immersed himself in American culture complete with Harley Davidson.

Ross had a strong moral and work ethic, and his individual style of management and fairness ensured respect from everyone in the business.   His career path which took him through Digital, HP, Smart, Force, Motorola and Emmerson was exemplary and the Leaders
at all these Companies chose Ross because they knew what he was made of and that he would get the job done, on time and with no fuss.  He led from the front with his generosity, honesty and integrity. Many emails have been received with the stories from people who met and worked with him.  His career is something to be proud of.

Ross was an artist, and many may have seen his modern outlook on painting. His paintings may only have hung on his own walls but we all appreciated and liked his unique style. 

Ross was a biker through and through.  He loved the times he spent biking in the UK and the USA and kept in touch via Zoom calls with his biking group.  From the Yamaha to the Harley with Lucy riding pillion, those were some of his happiest times.

Ross preferred trucks rather than a sports car.  Who can forget the immaculate, pristine, blue Land Rover which was his pride and joy (even if it did have tiny wheels)?  Of course, Ross then had to
keep the DVLA happy and pay the VAT required when it changed from being an ‘off-road farm vehicle’ (with the previous ‘passenger’ in the back being a sheep) into a ‘domestic family vehicle’ - a small price to pay.

Ross was also an enthusiastic hands-on builder and no project was too daunting. The house in Ochiltree and both houses in Ayr all needed major work and Ross was the man to go for it.  His barbeque in Ayr was so impressive, South Ayrshire Council sent a representative from the Planning Dept. to come out and inspect it.

Ross loved his dogs from Rhanna (purchased in the Pub in Ochiltree – where else?) to his latest little pup, they were a constant in his life.

Ross was a keen and generous sailor and there were many great times and adventures on Sheika Baby. The trips through the Crinan Canal out to the Western Isles were stupendous, as were the many forays around Arran. Sailing stories are not always suitable for publication but Simon's trousers being hoisted to the top of the mast to dry, is an exception that makes us all smile. Ross always looked forward to coming back to Scotland for a weeks’ sailing with the boys. 

We were all looking forward to the new Fisher and Ross was so excited that it had bow thrusters, - what more could you ask for, but sadly, this could not be.  Life events changed very rapidly over the last few years and many plans had to change, with Ross settling back
in Ayr.

Whether it be Son, Brother, Husband, Father -  to many of us Ross was a friend – a great and true friend, and collectively we have no sad memories.  We will always remember with joy and laughter, the loss of a bet culminating in Ross having to wear one of Lucy’s
dresses to the Village pub; the Volvo versus the Rolex at one Hogmanay in Arran; The ‘my-wheels-are-bigger-than-your-wheels’ contest resolved only when Ross produced a tape measure; Tequila Slammers; great times in the Cherry Tree Inn after Badminton and creating innovative engineering designs in the bar and presenting the solution at work the following day.  So many more stories to remember and continue to share, and each and every one of them treasured, wonderful times with a loyal, true and good friend.

Slàinte mhath, Ross.

The RNLI is a vital organisation for all sailors and that is why this charity was so special to Ross.

As it’s my 70th birthday on the 3rd December.  The original party I had planned has had to be shelved. Instead I am asking for donations for the Penlee RNLI which I have been connected with since 1984.

My connection with the RNLI started with my Great grandfather who joined the Padstow RNLI in 1883, so the RNLI is in my blood. I am the 4th generation in the family my son and daughter are connected and my grandsons are stormforce members making six generations. The
crew at Penlee do a fantastic job all hours of the day or night, 365 days of the year. Please support my request.

Thank you Eric

paddling pool or even if you’re very own hot tub…if you’re lucky enough!

page and use the hashtag #BigRNLIDip.

story:
I've always found wonder and solace in the countryside. The impact we humans are having on the wild spaces, the biodiversity and the health of the planet is deeply troubling. The WWF is an immense force for good in the struggle to raise awareness of what is happening and to provide viable solutions for protecting the world's wildlife, now and for future generations. What better way to raise funds for the charity's work than to join in their Big Winter Wander and ask kind friends to sponsor us?

We're planning a 20K walk starting in Guildford, walking up through the woodlands called the Chantries to join the old Pilgrim's Way that runs along the ridge of the North Downs past St Martha's Church; we'll then drop back down to complete our circuit along the banks of the River Wey.

IF YOU GO DOWN TO THE WOODS TODAY

You might notice theres less wildlife than there used to be. Thats because half of all UK species are in decline  were losing our precious red squirrels, hedgehogs and birds at an alarming rate.

By taking part in The Big Winter Wander, you and your friends and family can reconnect with our countrys beautiful wildlife and help protect it. The funds you raise will help us campaign to protect wildlife here, and around the world.

Nature has been there to offer us comfort during difficult times, and now its our time to give back.

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: We are running 10km in Wimbledon Common because every person deserves clean water
pageSummaryWhat: We are running 10km in Wimbledon Common
story:
Our story begins when we were around the age of 4. We were able to walk to a tap and have free access to clean water and we hadn’t been educated that we were lucky yet. At the age of 4, you didn’t really get the meaning of life but now we do. We believe the meaning of life is to help others and yourself, and that led us on thinking that innocent people were suffering from having no other choice but to drink dirty, polluted water, which makes them very ill or worse still, they can die. 

We want to raise money for Water Aid by doing a 10km run. We are doing it in our Tiger onesies…just so we stand out and make it harder!  As we like to say, ‘you climb a mountain not so the world can see you but so you can see the world’. We just want to make a difference and that difference can be you by donating to our Justgiving page! One day you might be asked by your child…Daddy or Mummy how did you help people who needed clean water? What will you say?

Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in climate-vulnerable communities.
